ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned the basics of Japanese

Being in L2 I learned how to utilize grammar concepts I learned last semester such as the te-form of verbs in new grammar concepts. I also learned new tenses and forms of verbs. We also learned new vocabulary and kanji each week. We also learned about different things in Japanese culture such as hot springs.

Proficiency in Japanese reading, writing, and speaking. Improved fluency in everyday conversation. Deeper cultural insight into Japanese culture and the forms of communication used in both casual and formal settings. Greater confidence in Japanese skill.
Japanese vocab, grammar, reading, listening, speaking, composition. A little bit of Japanese culture, too.
We learned even more Kanji, more Japanese grammar and vocabulary, as well as about Japanese culture and practices.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was very strong overall and there was no way to be a part of the course without being fully engaged. I think the professor did the best job they could with virtual learning using many other online platforms outside of zoom for homework as well during class to provide us with the optimal virtual experience. Oftentimes in class, we would visit different websites such as a website with a map of the world where each of us pinned a place we visited and wrote a description for our classmates to read. Obviously, being a language class it wasn't exactly the same online but I think our professor utilized different internet resources to make up for this.

Strengths are that JAPN 120 follows naturally from JAPN 110 and there is not a significant jump in difficulty, which helps ease the transition. Syllabus also draws from the same textbook, so the material is consistent in both new content and allusions to past lessons. An inevitable weakness was the virtual format, which made it difficult to reach peak levels of engagement, but still a very enjoyable course.

A lot of exposure--I improved without noticing I improved. The writing and grammar exercises were helpful. I was able to practice speaking when I answered questioned during classes. I wish there could've been more vocab exercises--there were a lot of new vocab and we could've practiced them more so that I'd know how to use them better.

I think the only thing I would've changed about this year was if the lectures could be recorded so we could go back and check on some things if we were confused. Other than that I thought it was structured well, and fast enough that we were making progress but slow enough that it wasn't overwhelming.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the breakout rooms to practice with other students one on one was a nice way to practice or do exercising in a lower stakes environment. I think the different websites were we answered questions or did different posts were also helpful. I appreciated the video homework assignments which were usually fun to do as they were about interesting topics but also allowed us to practice the new concepts we learned.

Having an asynchronous day helped immensely with relieving stress and providing a flexible "break" halfway through the week. Regular virtual clinic sessions were very helpful for fielding personal questions and concerns.

The asynchronous classes weren't as help as they could've been. Most of these courses turned into 'shadowing' practices--reading/repeating conversations. It would've been more helpful if we could just reproduce the conversations on our own, with full understanding of the meanings. Sometimes the shadowing would turn into mechanical reproduction of the sound. But everything else was fine.
I think everything worked well, class was very engaging and since the class was so small it wasn't too bad being on zoom, and it was very easy to participate and remain active in class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this to somoene who is interested in learning Japanese and is serious about it and willing to put in the work. Being an L2 language course there is a lot of daily work and especially for Japanese there is always a lot of new vocab and kanji to learn each week but if a student is willing to put in the work they will learn a lot in just a semester.

I would highly recommend this course to a student who is looking to study a foreign language and has interest in Asian culture. The workload is definitely intense, as with all foreign language courses, but it was consistent with first semester Japanese so this was expected.
Yes. This course is what you gotta take if you wanna learn Japanese.

If you like Japanese and want to keep studying then you should definitely take this course, but if not it is a lot of work and is very time consuming. While you learn a lot of Japanese it takes a lot of effort to keep up in class.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We also recorded videos for homework on flipgrid, did shadowing exercises which we also recorded, and submitted writing assignments on Google's jam board.
One asynchronous class a week.
4 synchronous classes plus 1 asynchronous class every week.
